content.description: This route is about as close to gym-climbing as you can get without having to sign in... really sustained... good climb.  The crux is at the top at the same section of wall as One Step Beyond, only, this side is significantly more featured, making it a 10a.
content.location: First bolted line once you rap down from the top (near Bonsai Tsunami 5.11c)

content.description: Short and easy warm up climb for the El Nino Wall Area. Also a fun solo!
content.location: Very top of El Nino Wall on a small pinnacle formation.

content.description: Starts on a rock near a tree, rapp down to start, pull rope and lead up if u like. Pretty fun and easy.
content.location: Far right side on El Nino, Rap to start.

content.description:
There are two crux sections here.  The first is at the very start of the climb.  I don't want to give away too much because it's fun to try and figure out the beta.  I'll just say that it's a huge move to a side-pull with no feet.

The other crux is at the very top.  The climb goes from kinda slab to strait vertical for the last 10' or so.  this 10' section has small knobs...great for feet, not so great for hand holds.  There is a small roof that has a bomber undercling you'll use to throw a left hand out to a small crimper hold then you're at the anchor.
content.location: This climb is at the very bottom of El Niño Wall.  To get to the climb, rap down if you know the beta on that.  Otherwise, there is a trail that skirts the wall to the West.  Follow this down 'till the trail becomes level and start looking for a large crack that shoots up the wall.  The climb is just to the left of the crack, behind the small trees.

content.description: Very fun sporty climbing on jugs and edges up an arete.
content.location: Far right arete on El Nino Wall.

content.description: This climb is roughly a 5.10a but gains it's 11b from the obvious crux section at the top of the climb.  when you reach the top, there's a blank section of overhanging wall about 5' high that you have to reach over for a sloping, diagonal crimp.  once you have that hold, move your left foot high to a knob where you can drive through and reach the anchor.
content.location: first bolted line left of Close to the Edge

content.description: Furthest east route on El Nino; scramble up low 5th class terrain right of Swoosh to a steeper face above.

Though the route as a whole is not terribly sustained, the cruxes are interesting and high-quality. A tenuous slab start leads to a horizontal crack/rail and delightful small edges, then up toward a bulge at 65 ft; negotiate a delicate crux sequence here and finish on easier highly-featured terrain.
content.protection: 11 bolts, anchor/rap shuts on the large block atop the wall. 70M rope required for TR.
content.location: Walk/scramble to the east side of the El Nino formation and rappel down to a mildly brushy alcove just above the base of the wall. April Showers starts 25' higher up, atop blocks and shrubs. A second short rappel or steep squeeze-chimney down-climb may be necessary to reach the base of the wall and the true start of Mud Slide. I found difficulties around 5.10 when I moved left to the second bolt from the alcove, rather than start at the base of the wall. This is a reasonable variation for those with a 60M rope wishing to TR.

content.description: Sport climb up the middle of High Rise face.
content.location: bolted route to the right of High Rise Dihedral

content.description: 2 pitch dihedral on el nino wall. Somewhat runout. Good route to access routes on the upper wall.
content.location: obvious dihedral on el nino wall

content.description:
P.1 Heads up a nice 5.9 crack with a little roof to navigate around.  Worth doing on its own.

P.2 Heads up 5.12b on bolts to the top of the El Nino formation.
content.protection: Cams to .3-4"?  and quickdraws.  Haven't climbed it yet but it looks even better in real life than it does in the photo.
content.location: Starts at the base of the El Nino wall, in the center.

content.description: Climb the arete at the bottom of the 3rd class scramble on the climber's left side of the formation. Start in a small dihedral with a small, broken finger crack on the left, then pull out of the dihedral (crux) up onto the arete proper. About 10-15 feet of 5.10 climbing up small crimps and textured slopes on the rounded arete, then the climbing eases significantly on the lower-angle, highly featured arete. There are open shuts at the top of the arete (at around 90 ft.) Stop here, or continue up the low-angle ledge around to climber's left w/ very easy climbing (5-nothing) to the top of the El Nino formation.
content.protection:
This is a bolted climb. Open cold shuts at about 90ft. up, at the top of the arete. Sparsely protected but easy climbing climber's left once on the ledge will gain closed shut anchors at the top of the formation. A SINGLE ROPE RAP FROM THE TOP

WILL NOT

GET YOU TO THE BASE, it's about 150 ft. to rap from the top.
content.location: Scramble down (3rd class) on climber's left side of the formation to the "corner" at the bottom. This is probably the best and fastest option. A double rope rap from anchors at the top will also get you down safely and allow a safe toproped climb. If you don't mind rapping off sketchy "open cold shuts" you can rap down with a single rope from the top to the intermediate ledge, and then rap again from your choice of several open cold shut anchors. This climb is right of Vortex and left of the trad dihedral climb High Rise.

content.description: The crux section is actually a new progression in this route.  Fred re-bolted this one so that you have to shift onto the areté from the face after the first or second bolt. There's this sharp right-hand crimp I kinda had to throw to but the feet are good.
content.location:
El Niño Wall

You'll have to rap down to lead this route.

Set up a top belay to climb out.

Reference ACSD Pocket Guide

content.description: Rap in to start. Small slab start to right facing flaw then small mantle to horizontal flaw and precise climbing through quartz crystal to smooth surface on edge of very large ledge. Continue to follow bolts up highly textured wall to anchors. There is about 30 feet between the last bolt and anchor. This run out can be easily protected with small nuts, or you can safely run it out to the anchors.
content.protection: Five bolts below ledge and about five bolts above. Optional small nuts for last 30 feet. Anchors are closed shuts.
content.location: Cake walk is located between Twister and Mud Slide. Pass Twister and tunnel below bolder on left then imediately turn right and reach the edge by again tunneling between boulders. Look right to find anchors.

content.description: Start atop blocks on the far right side of El Nino and move left through the lowest-angled section of the wall. Pass 3 bolts and a large hollow flake on your way up to a small ledge and a steeper crux section just above.
content.location: Rappel in from top of the wall to start.
